title: 108_s2244
content: The bill is titled the "Freedom to Fish Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that recreational fishing is the most popular outdoor sport with over 50 million participants nationwide, contributing $116 billion annually to the economy and supporting over 1.2 million jobs in the United States. Recreational fishing in the United States supports over 1.2 million jobs, contributing to local economies and small businesses in communities reliant on seasonal tourism. Anglers also show a conservation ethic by paying taxes and fees on fishing equipment and licenses. Recreational anglers contribute over $500 million annually to State fisheries conservation programs. Federal policy supports public access to public lands for recreational purposes in line with conservation principles. The federal policy supports public access to public lands and waters for recreational purposes in line with conservation principles, as reflected in various acts. Recreational fishery resources can be maintained through management measures without restricting public access to fishing areas. Recreational fishing can be managed through various measures like take limits, size requirements, and closed seasons, without unnecessarily prohibiting it. A clear policy is needed to show anglers that recreational fishing can be sustained. Additionally, a comprehensive policy on marine protected areas is necessary to balance recreational fishing with conservation efforts. The United States promotes conservation of fishery resources by ensuring federal regulations provide access to fishing areas for recreational anglers, involving them in regulatory procedures, and imposing limitations only when scientifically necessary for conservation. SEC. 4. MAGNUSON-STEVENS FISHERY CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACT AMENDMENTS. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to limit closures of recreational fishing areas unless there is clear evidence that recreational fishing is causing a specific conservation issue and no other conservation measures are effective. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to restrict closures of recreational fishing areas unless there is clear evidence that recreational fishing is causing a specific conservation issue and no other conservation measures are effective. The management plan must include specific measurable criteria to assess the conservation benefits of the prohibition and require a review of the need for the prohibition at least once every 3 years. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act requires periodic reviews to assess the need for closing recreational fishing areas based on scientific evidence supporting conservation benefits. The prohibition is lifted when the condition justifying it no longer exists. Technical amendments are also made to the Act. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act allows for the lifting of prohibitions on recreational fishing areas when the conditions justifying them no longer exist. Technical amendments are made to the Act to refine certain paragraphs. The National Marine Sanctuaries Act is being amended. Section 304(a)(5) of the National Marine Sanctuaries Act is amended to allow Regional Fishery Management Council to draft fishing regulations for the exclusive economic zone. The Regional Fishery Management Council may draft fishing regulations for the exclusive economic zone in accordance with the Magnuson Act, with approval from the State Governor if regulating a fishery within a state. The Regional Fishery Management Council may regulate a fishery within a State if the Governor approves or the Secretary determines that the State's actions will adversely affect the fulfillment of regulations. The Secretary may regulate a fishery within a State if the State's actions will substantially affect the goals of the Act and the proposed designation. Notification and hearing procedures will be followed in such cases. The Secretary may regulate a fishery within a State if it will substantially affect the goals of the Act. Notification and hearing procedures will be followed in such cases. The Secretary may regulate a fishery within a State if it substantially affects the Act's goals. Notification and hearing procedures will be followed in such cases. The Secretary shall conduct a hearing before regulating a fishery within a State under certain conditions. If the Secretary assumes regulation of a fishery in a state, the state can request reinstatement of authority. The Secretary must promptly terminate the regulation if the reasons for assuming it no longer apply.
